text: Robert Bruce Grady (12 January 1943 - 18 October 2014) was an engineer who was an expert in software development. He attended the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), graduating in 1965 with a bachelor's degree in electrical engineering. He was a member of Sigma Phi Epsilon fraternity, and he was a star player on the MIT basketball team. In 1965 he received the Howard W. Johnson Award for Male Senior Athlete of the Year, which is given to only one athlete per year across all athletics at MIT.MIT Howard A Johnson Award for Male Senior Athlete of the Year, URL http://mitathletics.com/information/excellence/Johnson_Award, accessed 10 November 2014 (Award prior to 1991 known as Class of 1948 Award.(Clifford Award?)) Grady wrote three books on software metrics and project management: Software Metrics: Establishing a Company-Wide Program (with Deborah L. Caswell)Prentice-Hall, Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey, 1987, , Practical Software Metrics for Project Management and Process Improvement, and Successful Software Process Improvement. Grady and Caswell's first book, Software Metrics, has been cited 661 times in other scholarly articles and publications.Google citation count, accessed 10 November 2014. ==References== Category:1943 births Category:2014 deaths Category:American software engineers Category:American electrical engineers Category:MIT Engineers men's basketball players Category:American men's basketball players
